body:
Some feedback from using the Logger view; feel free to break into separate issues:

- [x] when appending, the last item doesn't scroll into view (the last - 1 does)
- [x] it would be great if the text filter was live (filtering as you type, not just on return)
- [x] long text is truncated - we need to query the VM for the full value (which will be async, so we'll need to be careful to keep the original ordering of the log items) (#3052)
- [ ] we should display the 'error' and 'stackTrace' fields from dart:developer log() calls
- [x] we should have a way to display the severity (or at least, call out error level and warning level)
- [x] decide whether we do need to display the timestamp column (#2457)
- [x] we should devote more of the horizontal space to the message portion of the log entry (#2457)
- [x] stack traces don't look clickable, and don't jump to a location when clicked (#2402)
- [x] we should provide a visual separator after reloads and restarts (in the text console, we clear the console) (#2458)

/cc @pq

comment_data.body: One more item; when run in Debug mode, the view has less horizontal space available to it: Much of the text that I want to see (the log message text) is now off the screen. We should consider making the non-message portion of the log entry more compact. Some ideas are to remove the entry timestamp, to move the entry timestamp column to the right side of the view, to use icons instead of text labels for log severity, ...

Awesome feedback.  Along these lines a few things I've been mulling over:

* how "sticky" should modifications be?  (IOW: if I hide a column once, should it stick to the next session?)
* would auto-hiding columns in narrow contexts be surprising?
* would it be odd to have different default layouts in run vs. debug views?

Input welcome!

> would auto-hiding columns in narrow contexts be surprising?

It would be great if the user didn't need to hide columns - if the default layout was one we thought they could run with.

I would be great if we can make default layout like this one:

![flutter_log_console_tab](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6185205/41672930-713f7892-74e5-11e8-804f-23b2cc03628a.gif)

Having a separate tab is an interesting idea.  Our thinking was that it is often useful to see both at once since logging information complements debugging.  In any case, striving for a layout that makes this at least _possible_ is a good thing to strive towards.

Having long text wrap would be fantastic! Being able to see the text for long lines is one of the advantages of a pure text console - either via horz. scrolling or wrapping the text. Unfortunately I'm not familiar enough with `ColoredTableCellRenderer` myself to advise.

The item at the top - `long text is truncated` - refers to something slightly different. The text we get from the VM for some events is truncated, at like ~70 chars or so. We can recognize when this is the case, and should query the VM for the full text (https://github.com/flutter/flutter-intellij/blob/master/src/io/flutter/logging/FlutterLogEntryParser.java#L73).

@devoncarew @pq Do you have any suggestion how we can query to the Dart VM to get the full log.
I've checked but can't found the solution :|

Yup, on the vm service, you'll want to call the `getObject()` method. Given an String object that has a truncated string value, I believe that getObject() will return the full value.

https://github.com/dart-lang/sdk/blob/master/runtime/vm/service/service.md#getobject
Thank you, I will continue checking :)

@devoncarew, @pq our log entry almost come from `ProcessHandler` callback.
as I check, we don't have any log come from VmService (calblack) :|

Not currently, but we do plan to add logging to the Flutter framework, which will be based on the dart:developer log() call; we'll receive that as `_Logging` events.

You can simulate this currently by adding `import dart:developer;` in a flutter app, and then in the app, call `log('Foo bar');`.

Oh, I got it.
Thank you!

> You can simulate this currently by adding import dart:developer; in a flutter app, and then in the app, call log('Foo bar');.

üëç 

I'm playing with this right now.  (Specifically for platform channel communications.)

@quangson91: let me know and I can cc you w/ progress.
Closing as this is related to the experimental logging view.

milestone.description: Issues under consideration for upcoming milestones.
milestone.title: On Deck

title: Logger view punchlist
